|Description=Treatment of venous line infection and thrombosis
|Rubric=Management
|Contributors= Philippe Lacroix, Simon Rickenbach
|Order=7}}

Infectious complications

If there are any signs of infection, the equipment should be removed. The catheter is cultured.

If there are general signs, blood cultures are taken ('''[[Positive blood culture SD-190|positive blood culture]]'''').

The decision to introduce antibiotic therapy depends on whether the symptoms are local or general ('''[[Prescribe an anti-infective SD-255|prescribe an anti-infective]]'''):

- in the event of fever, general signs of sepsis or even septic shock, antibiotic therapy is initiated

- antibiotic therapy targets staphylococci aureus and epidermidis.

- it is extended to Gram bacilli - in cases of immunodepression, neutropenia or other risk factors

Thrombotic complications

In the event of central venous thrombosis, the catheter may be left in place if it is functional, with prescription of curative anticoagulation adapted to the context.

question.title: What is the next step in the management of a patient with a suspected central venous line infection?
question.description: Select the best course of action

option_a.title: Remove and replace the catheter
option_a.description: This is the standard procedure for infected central venous lines

option_b.title: Continue to use the catheter with antibiotic therapy
option_b.description: This may be appropriate for catheters with minor signs of infection

option_c.title: Take blood cultures and observe for signs of sepsis
option_c.description: This is a general approach to managing suspected infections

option_d.title: Prescribe anticoagulation to prevent further thrombosis
option_d.description: This is a common approach to managing central venous thrombosis
